com.rli.util.identityData

Class IdentityData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rli.util.identityData.IdentityData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ChangeEvent

    public class IdentityData
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    This class represents a set of attributes and their corresponding value(s) for one specific identity or entry. Note: although this class is named IdentityData, it can be used to represent any kind of entry.

    This class includes support for the following types of attributes:
    - attributes with a single String value, e.g: firstName = "Susie"
    - attributes with multiple String values, e.g: city = [ "Novato", "Chicago", "New York ]
    - attributes with a single complex value, e.g: name = { "first": "John", "last": "Smith" }
    - attributes with multiple complex values, e.g: name = [ { "first": "John", "last": "Smith" }, { "first": "Jane", "last": "Smith" }]

    Note: for a given attribute name, this class does not support having a mix of both String values and complex values. An attribute can have either String values or complex values, but not both.

    Examples:

    Example #1: Creating a basic entry:
    IdentityData newEntry = new IdentityData();
    // cn, sn, and givenName are single-valued attributes
    newEntry.addAttribute("cn", "John Smith");
    newEntry.addAttribute("sn", "Smith");
    newEntry.addAttribute("givenName", "John");
    // mail and objectclass are multi-valued attributes
    newEntry.addAttribute("mail", "jsmith@radiantlogic.com", "jsmith@gmail.com");
    newEntry.addAttribute("objectclass", "top", "person", "organizationalPerson", "inetOrgPerson");

    Example #2: Creating an entry with some complex attributes (similar to SCIM entries):
    IdentityData newEntry = new IdentityData();
    // userName is a single-valued attribute
    newEntry.addAttribute("userName", "dschrute");

    // name is a single-valued complex attribute with 3 sub-attributes: givenName, middleName, and familyName
    ComplexValue nameComplexValue = new ComplexValue();
    nameComplexValue.add("givenName", "Dwight");
    nameComplexValue.add("middleName", "Kurt");
    nameComplexValue.add("familyName", "Schrute");

    newEntry.addComplexAttribute("name", nameComplexValue);

    // phoneNumbers is a multi-valued complex attribute with 2 sub-attributes: type and value
    ComplexValue workPhoneValue = new ComplexValue();
    workPhoneValue.add("type", "work");
    workPhoneValue.add("value", "555-555-8377");

    ComplexValue homePhoneValue = new ComplexValue();
    homePhoneValue.add("type", "home");
    homePhoneValue.add("value", "555-333-4322");

    newEntry.addComplexAttribute("phoneNumbers", workPhoneValue, homePhoneValue);

      • getFirstValueAsString

        public java.lang.String getFirstValueAsString(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the first value associated with the specified attribute. If the value is a complex value, the value will be returned as a JSON Object String, e.g: {"city":["Novato"],"zipcode":["94945"]} . If no value has been set for the attribute, or if the attribute does not exist, returns null.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The first value associated with the specified attribute.

      • getValuesAsString

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getValuesAsString(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the list of values associated with the specified attribute. If the values are complex values, the values will be returned as a list of JSON Object String, e.g: {"city":["Novato"],"zipcode":["94945"]} . If no value has been set for the attribute, or if the attribute does not exist, returns an empty list.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The list of values associated with the specified attribute.

      • getNullSafeValuesAsString

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getNullSafeValuesAsString(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the list of values associated with the specified attribute. If the values are complex values, the values will be returned as a list of JSON Object String, e.g: {"city":["Novato"],"zipcode":["94945"]} . If no value has been set for the attribute, or if the attribute does not exist, returns an empty list. Note: this method is safe to use even if the specified attribute name is null.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The list of values associated with the specified attribute.

      • getFirstComplexValue

        public ComplexValue getFirstComplexValue(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the first complex value of the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist. If the attribute contains a non-complex value (such as a basic String value), this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. To avoid this exception, you can call the isAttributeValueComplex(String) method to first check if an attribute is complex before calling this method.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The first complex value of the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist.

      • getComplexValues

        public java.util.List<ComplexValue> getComplexValues(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the list of complex values associated with the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist. This method will also return null if an empty set of values is found for the specified attribute. If the attribute contains a non-complex value (such as a basic String value), this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. To avoid this exception, you can call the isAttributeValueComplex(String) method to first check if an attribute is complex before calling this method.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The list of complex values associated with the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist.

      • containsAttribute

        public boolean containsAttribute(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Indicates whether this IdentityData contains the specified attribute.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of an attribute.
        Returns:
        true if this IdentityData contains the specified attribute, or false otherwise.

      • containsComplexAttributeValue

        public boolean containsComplexAttributeValue(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Indicates whether this IdentityData contains an attribute that has at least one complex value.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of an attribute.
        Returns:
        true if this IdentityData objects contains the specified attribute, and if that attribute has at least one complex value. Returns false otherwise.

      • isAttributeValueComplex

        public boolean isAttributeValueComplex(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Indicates whether the specified attribute contains a ComplexValue value.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of an attribute.
        Returns:
        true if the specified attribute contains a ComplexValue value, or false otherwise.

com.rli.util.identityData

Class IdentityData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rli.util.identityData.IdentityData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ChangeEvent

    public class IdentityData
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    This class represents a set of attributes and their corresponding value(s) for one specific identity or entry. Note: although this class is named IdentityData, it can be used to represent any kind of entry.

    This class includes support for the following types of attributes:
    - attributes with a single String value, e.g: firstName = "Susie"
    - attributes with multiple String values, e.g: city = [ "Novato", "Chicago", "New York ]
    - attributes with a single complex value, e.g: name = { "first": "John", "last": "Smith" }
    - attributes with multiple complex values, e.g: name = [ { "first": "John", "last": "Smith" }, { "first": "Jane", "last": "Smith" }]

    Note: for a given attribute name, this class does not support having a mix of both String values and complex values. An attribute can have either String values or complex values, but not both.

    Examples:

    Example #1: Creating a basic entry:
    IdentityData newEntry = new IdentityData();
    // cn, sn, and givenName are single-valued attributes
    newEntry.addAttribute("cn", "John Smith");
    newEntry.addAttribute("sn", "Smith");
    newEntry.addAttribute("givenName", "John");
    // mail and objectclass are multi-valued attributes
    newEntry.addAttribute("mail", "jsmith@radiantlogic.com", "jsmith@gmail.com");
    newEntry.addAttribute("objectclass", "top", "person", "organizationalPerson", "inetOrgPerson");

    Example #2: Creating an entry with some complex attributes (similar to SCIM entries):
    IdentityData newEntry = new IdentityData();
    // userName is a single-valued attribute
    newEntry.addAttribute("userName", "dschrute");

    // name is a single-valued complex attribute with 3 sub-attributes: givenName, middleName, and familyName
    ComplexValue nameComplexValue = new ComplexValue();
    nameComplexValue.add("givenName", "Dwight");
    nameComplexValue.add("middleName", "Kurt");
    nameComplexValue.add("familyName", "Schrute");

    newEntry.addComplexAttribute("name", nameComplexValue);

    // phoneNumbers is a multi-valued complex attribute with 2 sub-attributes: type and value
    ComplexValue workPhoneValue = new ComplexValue();
    workPhoneValue.add("type", "work");
    workPhoneValue.add("value", "555-555-8377");

    ComplexValue homePhoneValue = new ComplexValue();
    homePhoneValue.add("type", "home");
    homePhoneValue.add("value", "555-333-4322");

    newEntry.addComplexAttribute("phoneNumbers", workPhoneValue, homePhoneValue);

        public ComplexValue getFirstComplexValue(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the first complex value of the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist. If the attribute contains a non-complex value (such as a basic String value), this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. To avoid this exception, you can call the isAttributeValueComplex(String) method to first check if an attribute is complex before calling this method.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The first complex value of the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist.

      • getComplexValues

        public java.util.List<ComplexValue> getComplexValues(java.lang.String attributeName)
        Returns the list of complex values associated with the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist. This method will also return null if an empty set of values is found for the specified attribute. If the attribute contains a non-complex value (such as a basic String value), this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. To avoid this exception, you can call the isAttributeValueComplex(String) method to first check if an attribute is complex before calling this method.
        Parameters:
        attributeName - The name of the attribute.
        Returns:
        The list of complex values associated with the specified attribute or null if the attribute does not exist.
